title: Almagua Social DAO Project
description: In Colombia, a platform of initiatives is needed that encourages projects for the communities

f6_assessments.q0:
While no directly aimed at producing tools, this proposal intends to spend funds to prepare a pitch deck and participate in Milkomeda hackathon. It will result in producing a tool indirectly, through secondary effect. Connecting to physical communities in Amazon and measuring impact directly is something DAOs really need. What is missing is more detailed information about the tool, the issue itself is a complex one and more information about the components of the tool would be good, to better estimate the impact.
The risks and mitigation strategies should be better defined. Maybe try to find a developer or a tech consultant that would be able to codevelop this proposal?
f6_assessments.q1: Building a pitch deck in the funds requested is feasible, so no doubts here. A more details of the idea would be needed to estimate its feasibility. It's understandable that a fine-grain design of the tool is the purpose of the proposal, but nevertheless it would be more convincing if certain details about the proposed solution would be given. For example: Have any local communities been contacted or a list prepared? What projects that the tool would be used for? What kind of functionalities are expected from the tool? (What use cases are envisioned?)
f6_assessments.q2: The measurement of the project progress and its results is lacking. A pitch deck and a token are not enough of deliverables. What about the design and implementation of the tool? There are no mentions of reports, documentation, etc. Considering the budget for the proposal, maybe that's why they are missing? If so it would be best to somewhat increase funds in order to provide deliverables that would help in building tools for DAOs on Cardano, which is the main goal of this challenge.

f6_assessments.q0: According to the proponent, there should be a platform of initiatives that encourage projects for the community in Colombia. So this proposal wants to implement a social DAO for the Cardano community to vote on social and environmental projects, which will later be funded for their development. I believe this proposal is a smart fit for the goals of the challenge. One problem, however, is that even though the solution description fits the challenge, it makes sense in terms of the idea of ​​the proposal, the absence of a blueprint greatly affects the testability of the proposal. So even though the idea is good and can be successfully implemented, we cannot know how it will be implemented. The proponent should be more explicit about how the project will bring value to the Cardano ecosystem and how it is sustainable or how it can grow in the future, once funded and after the funding is spent. In addition, the challenges and risks that may be encountered during the implementation of the project are very poorly described, the main risk here is that the author is not a developer and he thinks he can get support from people in the community who can solve this problem. What if in the course of the project he does not find support? I think it is more convincing if you have a qualified team to work on the project before proposing it, unfortunately, there is no certainty in this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
The project plan is not convincing what is presented: "In Q2 2022 join the Milkomeda hackathon
Create a Cardano token at Cardano-native-token.com and add liquidity
Marketing project to create community discord, telegram, and other networks based on the initiative"
Perhaps there is confusion about the author's timing, as it is currently Q3 2022, it can be seen that the author plans to list some of the work he plans to do. We don't know exactly when these activities will take place, how long each activity will last, or how and who will do it? Next is the budget, the proposed request is quite modest: $3000 and explained to be used for the creation of advertising and marketing tokens. Although the required budget is low, we also need to be explained exactly how this money will be allocated to the activities. We couldn't figure out what the author's advertising strategy was, how long it took, and how much it cost. And finally, about the team, recommendation writer Sergio Gonzalez is an active member of the almagua foundation and also provides his LinkedIn profile. As mentioned since the author is not a developer he is looking for people with Haskell skills with a particular focus on DAO architecture and implementation. Based on the above information, I believe that the author is an idealist and wants to contribute his idea to contribute to the development of the Cardano ecosystem, but it is not enough information to convince me that the project can be done successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: The author states that project oversight can be reflected in the 8 day milkomeda hackathon and offers several ways for it to be developed in the process Almagua tokens will be generated in the Cardano network to promote tokens to obtain resources for the fund's projects, of which this DAO initiative is included as the first case and will be promoted between Catalyst and the Cardano community. This looks more like the author's intention than how people can track the progress of the project. Actually, without a concrete roadmap, we cannot visualize the process of the project, so my suggestion is that this roadmap is elaborated in detail, then the proponent and future team will give an overview of how activities are going each month, not only of the partial results obtained but also of how they work hours, whether everything is going according to plan or not? In addition, the proposal should provide additional means such as a website or any social networking site to update the progress of the project for the community to follow.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal has been vying the Cardano Project Catalyst funding since fund 6. Unfortunately the community hasn't been able to fund the project($3000). 

This proposal plans to include the population in Latin America and Columbia into the DAO environment based on Cardano. Hence making them a rational part of the economy. This is done by reaching out to the population in Columbia and the taking advantage of the political influence/reach of the cardano community in the process.

The details of the extent of foundations reach is unclear. The website FoundacionAlmagua.org does not have much information about the same. So I'm only to infer that the foundation is in initial stages of growth.

The final goal of the project is to create a AMALGUA token on Cardano Block chain and use it to reduce the carbon footprint, by mitigating/subsidising.

The only thing lacking  is that the proposer could have reached out to the community member for guidance/assistance on token development and could have mentioned the same in the proposal. This however can also be discussed at a later point.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal addresses the problem of marginalized Columbian communities and their need for a social initiative platform. The proposal to address this problem is the creation of a social DAO on Cardano in which the Almagua Foundation and the Cardano community create and vote on projects that benefit vulnerable communities of Columbia. However, the challenge for DAOs <3 Cardano is to create tools to build DAOs in Cardano. The questions to consider in this challenge include: how can we make Cardano the go-to choice for building DAOs? What tools can we provide to enable effective DAO's Creation & Operation? As the brief explains, the campaign seeks to address the issue that currently if a "DAO (even one that is aimed to build products and services around Cardano) wants to setup their DAO infrastructure, the current options are all based on, mostly, the Ethereum blockchain."
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal includes the proposer's LinkedIn profile link. The link works and the name of the proposer matches with the profile. The proposal also includes a YouTube video of the founders of the Almagua Foundation. It is a little over 2 minutes long and was posted 1 year ago. There was one other video posted on YouTube by the organization that was posted 2 years ago. Their channel has 13 followers and both videos had less than 100 views each. One of the videos included the organization's website. Verifying the validity of the website proved to be challenging as there is little information and dead links. The proposal lists actionable steps for completion include joining a Milkameda hackathon, creation of a native token, adding liquidity to the token, and marketing through Discord, Telegram, and other networks. However, a stronger proposal would include a timeline for completion of the tasks, a breakdown of expenses, a link to a website for the organization. After careful review of the funding rounds shared in the proposal, it was discovered that funds were awarded for Fund 6, however, the organization did not meet the requirements of the Caralyst monthly reports. They have not been given any of the $10,000 awarded to them. It appears that funding was not granted for Fund 7 and Fund 8. Feasibility for this proposal is questionable.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal lists items to measure for the success of the project to include participation in a hackathon, the creation of a pitch deck, the creation of an Almagua token, the distribution and promotion of the token throughout the Catalyst and Cardano Community. The audibility of this proposal is questionable. A stronger proposal would include a roadmap with measurable KPIs and time horizon and the ability of the community to monitor the progress of the project.

f6_assessments.q0: The project proposes the development of DAO based projects that focus on the financially excluded communities in Colombia. Though it is good that it targets communities that otherwise don’t have exposure to DAOs, it’s not clear what exactly these proposed projects will be. As such, it is a little difficult to definitively say the project will effectively address the challenge of making Cardano the ideal choice for building DAOs.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers mention some steps they will take to make this solution feasible. Though these are all necessary steps, it would have been better if a detailed timeline was provided on how they plan to achieve their goal. Since developing dApps will be the major part of this project, it’s essential that the project has developers as part of the team which currently it’s lacking.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal plans to measure the success of the project by tracking visible results from the beneficiary communities. The number/size of communities they plan to engage in these projects is not clearly stated and thus might pose a challenge in tracking the success of the project. It also would have given a better picture of how effective the proposed solution would be if the proposal mentioned anything about the flow of ADA after integrating the financially excluded communities into the ecosystem.
